blogs.title: My journey with loneliness
blogs.summary: I've experienced feeling lonely despite having supportive relationships. I realized the importance of connecting with myself and now recognize loneliness as a sign to focus on self-care and seek meaningful connections.
blogs.body:
The second I started writing this article, Boulevard of Broken Dreams inadvertently started playing in my mind (and now on my speakers). As someone who has written about loneliness in a more informative fashion before, I struggled with what new or innovative things to do with this piece. Until I realized that the reason why I am so drawn to the topic of loneliness is because of my own experience with it.
There is enough research out there to show the adverse effects of loneliness on us. However, what is so interesting to me is the contradiction which we are all fed. Our (Indian) society is a collectivist and interdependent one, which has always put emphasis on connection and maintaining relations. However, there are also deeply entrenched narratives of independence and being self-sufficient; so much so that many people struggle to ask for help. I have also struggled with the line between independence and interdependence, often oscillating between feelings of being lonely and being needy. What I mean by this is that I would simultaneously feel like I should not need any other human being, while also really craving connection and attention. I would not share my feelings with others, and also feel like nobody understood me. It was a paradox I have seen many people also struggle with.
I often felt content being by myself as it gave me a lot of time to explore my hobbies, but I am also a person who loves staying in touch with my loved ones. I love meeting my friends often, getting on regular calls or texting people to see how they are doing. As much as I need my “me time” I genuinely need my “we time” as well. However, I would also struggle if I were the one who constantly tried to be in touch. I would usually not reach out if I needed someone’s presence. The strangest thing is that I honestly have a great social support system. I have a family where, despite all our differences, I know that they will always have my back. I have friends who are there for me, who I feel comfortable with, and who I have genuine deep connections with. In fact, at every stage of my life, I have always found amazing friends. For over a decade I was almost always in a serious long-term romantic relationship. Even in the places where I worked I found incredible colleagues who were supportive and understanding. It confused me no end that I would struggle to reach out to people or feel lonely as often as I did despite being lucky in almost all social spheres of my life.
Loneliness always sneakily crept up on me. There was never any big event or trigger. Slowly, day after day, I would feel it become heavier on my chest. It took up almost the entire space in my body. I would talk to people and feel like nobody understood me. I would feel something and not know who to share it with. I would constantly crave somebody to talk to, but no matter who I spoke to that craving never left. Year after year, this loneliness has come and gone. It still comes and goes, but my relationship with it changed the more I understood it. An event that added to this understanding was when in my 3rd year of college I started feeling lonely all of a sudden. This was really strange for me because I lived on a residential campus, had a roommate I loved, friends I was constantly surrounded by, and a partner I was with almost the entire time. I was not craving a deep connection with anybody, I already had it, but I just kept on feeling like something was missing. It was turning into a feeling of emptiness for me, because I felt that if I could feel lonely even after everything I had, then there was no escape from that feeling. It was loneliness mixed with emptiness and helplessness. The only thing I could do was to reflect, to try and understand what it was that I was actually craving. After many days, I realized that what I was missing was actually a deeper connection with myself. Between all the time that I spent on my work and my relationships, I was not getting any time to truly be with myself, to connect with myself. I hardly ever did the things that only I wanted to do. Being social was somehow making me feel more lonely, because connection with others beyond a point requires a strong sense of self, otherwise what was I using to connect with anyone?
This was also coupled with the fear of college ending. All my closest friends were from different cities, and I was supposed to go abroad for my Master’s. I did not know what such distance would do to my friendships. The idea that not only my connection with myself was suffering, but soon my friendships might also potentially suffer, was a lot for me to take. At that time, however, confronting my loneliness became more about confronting myself rather than other people, because I could do nothing to stop college from ending (and the pandemic ended up speeding up that process). In fact, I don’t think I even shared my feelings with the people around me, even though this was adding to my loneliness.
Loneliness has also come to me in moments of isolation. In 2021, I finally left for London to pursue my Master’s. I had so many dreams and notions of how my life over there would be. It was the typical study abroad Instagram life, where I would meet so many people, go out and have endless experiences, and would just be extremely busy. However, this was far from the reality that I experienced. The pandemic had ensured that it would be difficult to socialize normally. In general I take time to make friends, but there was an added hurdle with classes not occurring offline and there not being enough opportunities to socialize with my peers. I had no family or friends in London, and in most moments I felt utterly alone. I remember falling sick in London, and being so afraid because there was nobody to take care of me (my thoughts took a much darker turn than just that though). For the first time I had the chance to truly understand the difference between isolation and loneliness, because I genuinely did not have people around me whenever I wanted. I was also going through a break up at that time which only added to my feelings of isolation. Even when I made good friends in London, it was not always possible to meet them every time I wanted to do something. It was only after quite a while, and honestly because there was no choice, that I used it as a chance to finally connect with myself. I learnt how to do anything and everything alone. I learnt how to spend hours and hours by myself and not feel lonely. In fact, I learnt to truly enjoy my solitude. Not to say that I did not feel lonely at all, and that I did not also spend hours on video calls with my loved ones back at home. But I was able to distinguish between craving company so that I wouldn’t feel lonely, and craving company because I genuinely enjoyed spending time with that person. It is a distinction that has truly come in handy to battle my loneliness now, because everytime I would socialize just to not be alone, I would stop myself and try to reflect on what was truly going on. I became even more certain that loneliness for me was more about connection with myself than just about connection with others.
So, what I have learnt from my loneliness is that it has many shades. There is the kind of loneliness which is more about isolation, and genuinely not having people around you for support. That is the kind that can be extremely difficult to deal with and requires measures to build a support system. But if you have experienced loneliness like me, the kind that comes from not having a deep connection with yourself, then that can be tricky to recognise and deal with. It can actually be a signal to pay more attention to yourself. Loneliness has become an alarm for me, especially when I use other people to run away from it. In those cases, I always know that something deeper is going on, and that I require my own attention, not somebody else’s. No matter how many friends you make, that kind of loneliness only goes away with solitude. There are likely many more shades of loneliness that I am yet to experience, and some that may be too much for this piece (and myself) to contain. But my hope with loneliness is to be able to look at it the way I look at all other emotions - passengers in a car that I am driving.

blogs.title: How to Cope with Holiday Stress
blogs.summary: Tips to manage stress during the holidays and maintain mental balance while celebrating.
blogs.body:
The holiday season is often associated with joy and celebration, but for many, it also brings stress and anxiety. From financial pressures to family dynamics, the holidays can feel overwhelming. This blog explores practical strategies for managing holiday stress and maintaining mental balance.

One of the most common sources of holiday stress is the expectation to create perfect celebrations. Social media often exacerbates this by showcasing idealized versions of holiday gatherings. To counter this, focus on what truly matters to you. Prioritize meaningful connections and activities over superficial perfection.

Financial stress is another significant challenge during the holidays. Gift-giving, travel, and hosting can strain budgets, leading to anxiety. Setting a realistic budget and sticking to it can alleviate this burden. Consider alternative gift options, such as handmade items or experiences, which can be more meaningful and less costly.

Family gatherings can sometimes trigger stress due to unresolved conflicts or differing expectations. It's essential to set boundaries and communicate openly with loved ones. If certain topics are off-limits or specific dynamics are challenging, establish ground rules to ensure a harmonious environment.

Self-care is crucial during the holiday season. Amidst the hustle and bustle, carve out time for activities that rejuvenate you, whether it's reading a book, taking a walk, or practicing mindfulness. Remember that it's okay to say no to events or commitments that feel overwhelming.

Mindfulness can be particularly effective in managing holiday stress. Techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or journaling can help you stay grounded and present. By focusing on the here and now, you can reduce the impact of stressors and enjoy the moment.

Another key aspect of managing holiday stress is seeking support when needed. Talk to friends or family members about your feelings, or consider speaking with a mental health professional if the stress becomes unmanageable. There's no shame in reaching out for help.

In conclusion, while the holidays can be a challenging time, they also offer opportunities for joy and connection. By prioritizing your mental health, setting realistic expectations, and practicing self-care, you can navigate the season with greater ease and fulfillment. Remember, the true spirit of the holidays lies in the moments of love, gratitude, and togetherness.

blogs.title: The Art of Practicing Mindfulness
blogs.summary: An introduction to mindfulness and its impact on reducing anxiety and improving mental health.
blogs.body:
Mindfulness is a transformative practice that has gained widespread attention for its ability to enhance mental well-being. At its core, mindfulness involves being fully present in the moment, without judgment. This blog delves into the science and benefits of mindfulness, offering insights and practical exercises to help you integrate it into your daily life.

The origins of mindfulness can be traced back to ancient traditions, particularly in Buddhism. However, modern mindfulness has been adapted to suit diverse needs, making it accessible to people of all backgrounds. Research has shown that mindfulness can reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression, improve focus and concentration, and enhance emotional regulation.

One of the key benefits of mindfulness is its ability to reduce stress. When we practice mindfulness, we shift our attention away from worries about the past or future, allowing us to focus on the present. This shift can have a calming effect on the mind and body, reducing the physiological effects of stress.

Mindfulness also promotes self-awareness, helping us recognize patterns in our thoughts and behaviors. By becoming more aware of our inner experiences, we can respond to challenges with greater clarity and intention. For example, instead of reacting impulsively to a stressful situation, mindfulness allows us to pause, reflect, and choose a more constructive response.

Practicing mindfulness doesn't require special equipment or extensive training. Simple exercises such as mindful breathing, body scans, and gratitude journaling can be incorporated into your routine. For instance, mindful breathing involves focusing on your breath as it flows in and out, gently bringing your attention back whenever it wanders. This practice can be done anywhere and takes only a few minutes.

Another effective way to practice mindfulness is through meditation. Guided meditations, which are widely available online, can help you develop your practice by providing structure and support. Over time, regular meditation can enhance your ability to stay present and cultivate a sense of inner peace.

Mindfulness extends beyond formal practices; it can be integrated into everyday activities. Whether you're eating, walking, or working, approaching these activities with mindfulness can deepen your connection to the present moment. For example, when eating mindfully, you savor each bite, paying attention to the flavors, textures, and sensations.

In conclusion, mindfulness is a valuable tool for enhancing mental health and well-being. By embracing mindfulness, you can reduce stress, improve self-awareness, and lead a more fulfilling life. Start small, and let mindfulness gradually become a natural part of your daily routine. Remember, the journey to mindfulness is a personal and ongoing process, and every step you take brings you closer to greater peace and balance.

blogs.title: Understanding and Managing Anxiety
blogs.summary: A comprehensive guide to recognizing anxiety symptoms and strategies for effective management.
blogs.body:
Anxiety is a common mental health challenge that affects millions worldwide, yet it remains widely misunderstood. This blog aims to shed light on anxiety, its symptoms, and effective strategies for management, empowering readers to take control of their mental well-being.

Anxiety can manifest in various forms, from generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) to panic attacks, social anxiety, and phobias. Each type has unique characteristics, but common symptoms include excessive worry, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, and physical sensations such as a racing heart or muscle tension. Recognizing these symptoms is the first step in addressing anxiety.

One of the challenges of anxiety is its tendency to create a vicious cycle. For example, worrying about a future event can trigger physical symptoms, which in turn amplify feelings of anxiety. Breaking this cycle requires a combination of awareness and proactive strategies.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a highly effective approach for managing anxiety. CBT helps individuals identify and challenge negative thought patterns, replacing them with more balanced and constructive perspectives. For instance, if you catch yourself thinking, "I can't handle this situation," CBT encourages you to reframe it as, "This situation is challenging, but I have the resources to manage it."

Relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, and visualization can also reduce anxiety symptoms. These practices calm the nervous system, making it easier to cope with stressful situations. Deep breathing, for instance, involves taking slow, deep breaths, which signals the body to relax and reduces the fight-or-flight response.

Lifestyle changes play a crucial role in managing anxiety. Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can significantly impact mental health. Exercise, in particular, has been shown to reduce symptoms of anxiety by releasing endorphins and promoting a sense of well-being.

Social support is another vital component of anxiety management. Talking to trusted friends or family members about your feelings can provide relief and perspective. Support groups and online communities also offer a safe space to share experiences and learn from others facing similar challenges.

For some individuals, professional help may be necessary. Therapists and counselors can provide tailored strategies for managing anxiety, while medication can be an option for those with severe symptoms. It's essential to consult a healthcare professional to determine the best course of action for your specific needs.

In conclusion, while anxiety can be overwhelming, it is also manageable with the right tools and support. By understanding anxiety, adopting effective strategies, and seeking help when needed, you can reduce its impact on your life and regain a sense of control and balance. Remember, managing anxiety is a journey, and every small step forward is a victory worth celebrating.

blogs.title: Balancing Mental Health and a Busy Career
blogs.summary: Practical tips for maintaining mental health while thriving in a demanding work environment.
blogs.body:
Balancing mental health and a busy career is no easy task, especially in today's fast-paced world. However, it is essential for long-term well-being and professional success. This blog explores practical strategies for maintaining mental health while navigating the demands of a busy career.

One of the keys to balance is effective time management. Prioritizing tasks and setting realistic goals can help reduce the overwhelming feeling of having too much on your plate. Tools like to-do lists, calendars, and productivity apps can assist in staying organized and focused.

Setting boundaries is another critical aspect of work-life balance. It's important to establish clear lines between work and personal life, such as not checking emails after office hours or dedicating weekends to family and leisure activities. Communicating these boundaries to colleagues and supervisors can help ensure they are respected.

Self-care is often neglected in the hustle of a busy career, but it is vital for mental health. Regular exercise, healthy eating, and sufficient sleep are foundational aspects of self-care. Additionally, finding time for hobbies and activities that bring joy can provide a much-needed mental reset.

Mindfulness and stress management techniques can also be valuable tools. Practices such as meditation, deep breathing, or yoga can help you stay grounded and manage stress effectively. Even taking a few moments during the workday to practice mindfulness can make a significant difference.

Support systems play a crucial role in maintaining mental health. Building strong relationships with colleagues, mentors, and friends can provide encouragement and perspective during challenging times. Don't hesitate to seek professional help if you're feeling overwhelmed; therapists and counselors can offer valuable guidance tailored to your needs.

It's also essential to evaluate your work environment and make adjustments if necessary. For instance, advocating for flexible work arrangements or exploring opportunities for career growth can enhance job satisfaction and reduce stress. If the demands of your job consistently exceed your capacity, it may be worth considering a change to protect your mental health.

In conclusion, balancing mental health and a busy career requires intentional effort and a commitment to self-care. By managing your time effectively, setting boundaries, and seeking support, you can thrive professionally while safeguarding your well-being. Remember, your mental health is your greatest asset, and investing in it is key to a fulfilling and successful career.

blogs.title: Mental Health Tips for Parents
blogs.summary: Guidance for parents to nurture their own mental health while supporting their children.
blogs.body:
Parenting is a rewarding journey, but it also comes with its unique challenges, particularly when it comes to maintaining mental health. This blog offers guidance for parents on how to nurture their own mental well-being while effectively supporting their children.

One of the first steps to maintaining mental health as a parent is recognizing the importance of self-care. Many parents prioritize their children's needs over their own, but neglecting self-care can lead to burnout. Taking time for activities that rejuvenate you, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time with friends, is essential for maintaining emotional balance.

Managing parental guilt is another critical aspect of mental health. It's natural to feel guilty about not being able to do it all, but it's important to remember that no parent is perfect. Setting realistic expectations for yourself and embracing the idea of "good enough" parenting can alleviate undue pressure.

Open communication is a cornerstone of healthy family dynamics. Encouraging your children to express their feelings and sharing your own emotions can foster a supportive environment. This not only helps children develop emotional intelligence but also strengthens the parent-child bond.

Creating a routine that balances family time and personal time is also beneficial. Scheduling regular family activities, such as game nights or outings, can create cherished memories while ensuring that parents have dedicated time for self-care and relaxation.

Seeking support when needed is vital for parents. Whether it's reaching out to friends, joining a parenting group, or consulting a therapist, having a support network can make a significant difference. Professional guidance can also provide strategies for managing stress and navigating challenging parenting situations.

Mindfulness can be a valuable tool for parents. Practices such as deep breathing, meditation, or journaling can help you stay present and manage stress effectively. Mindfulness can also enhance your ability to respond to your children's needs with patience and understanding.

Finally, modeling healthy behaviors is one of the most impactful ways to support your children's mental health. Demonstrating self-care, effective communication, and emotional regulation teaches children valuable life skills.

In conclusion, parenting is a journey that requires balancing the needs of your children with your own mental health. By prioritizing self-care, seeking support, and fostering open communication, you can create a healthy and nurturing environment for your family. Remember, taking care of yourself is not only beneficial for you but also sets a positive example for your children, helping them thrive in the long run.
